creditline: Gift of Elizabeth, Julie, and Catherine Andrus in memory of John and Marion Andrus
description: profile bust of a male figure facing R with tall hat, long white beard, and coat
markings: on verso: penned in brown ink, bottom center: P. Mariette (Lugt 1790) followed by 1672; black stamp, lower left: Ernst Theodor Rodenacker (Lugt 2438); two brown stamps, lower left, Berlin Print Room (Lugt 1608 and Lugt 234) with \"[a.?d.?] 1886\" in date field; brown stamp, left edge, Paul Davidsohn (Lugt 654); two undefined collector\'s marks at lower right
provenance: Pierre Mariette II, Paris, 1678; Ernst Theodor Rodenacker, Dantzig; Berlin Print Room, deaccessioned as duplicate, 1886('); Paul Davidsohn, Grunewald-Berlin; [C. & J. Goodfriend, New York, March 5, 1985; sold to Andrus]; John E. Andrus III, Wayzata, Minn.; by descent to his daughters, Elizabeth, Katie, and Julie. Earlier provenances have been gathered, but further research will increase our knowledge of their histories.
text: By the 1620s, the Dutch sought out tronies (head studies) as unvarnished glimpses into the human spirit. This rare early state shows Jan Lievens’ economical use of stippling and wiry lines to capture this (probably) live model, achieving the feel of a drawing. Like his friend Rembrandt, Lievens was born in Leiden, Holland, and was drawn to wizened faces.
title: Bust of an Old Man with a High Cap
